raft: As basic as it gets. Built by amatuer shipmakers, prison escapees and castaways the world over, this floating death trap is constructed by lashing bits of wood together.
skiff: Variations on this, most early of boat designs, are present in almost every country that could make textiles.
catamaran: The polynesians built one of the first catamaran designs. It was hundreds of years later that the design was revisited and became the ship we know today
cog: The earliest and most common ships in medieval times. It was large enough to carry goods and thus the shipping trade was invented.
corbita: The corbita was a trading ship used by the romans. Slightly smaller but faster than a standard cog.
maku: In 1281 the Mongol's invaded Japan with a huge armada of ships. They were smashed by a typhoon which was later called "divine wind" or "kamikaze" in Japanese
bune: These fortresses of the sea were imployed by the japanese in the 16th century. Their poor handling and speed due to their weight ment their use was short lived.
galley: The galley was the primary warship of the Greek's and later the Roman's. It has been in use, in one form or another, for over a millenia. A testiment to it's useful design.
dragon: The longship was most famously used by vikings. It's long thin hull and shallow draft made it fast with the ability to land on beach without the need for a intermediate cutter.
turtle: The Korean turtle ship, or Geobukseon as it was called colloquially, had metal deck plating and spikes to repel boarders. It was also quite manuverable and fast despite it's weight.
caravel: A portugese designed ship the Caravel was used to explore the West African coast. Most noteable were the Nina and Pinta that set out to discovered the New World in 1492
wako: The Wako was a Japanese pirate, the name was also used to describe their boats. Mainly used for ship to shore actions against the villages that dotted the chinese, japanese and korean.
sloop: A sloop-of-war was a blanket term for any ship with less than 20 guns. Their speed made them useful for escort duties and running down smaller ships in fleet actions.
junk: Chinese junk's were used for many roles through out history from a humble fishing vessel to a ship-of-war. Junk's are still in use today; a testiment to they're practical design.
schooner: A schooner had minimal to no armament but it's speed made it almost impossible for any armed ship to catch them. This fact made them useful as slavers, privateers and blockade runner.
carrack: The Carrack was of portugese design. It's spacious interior made it possible to hold large . Both Christopher Columbus and Magellan used made their famous voyages in a Carrack.
ironclad: With the development of the steam engine it was possible to clad warships with iron plates. The armor fixed the woodern ships tendency to catch on fire when hit with incendiary shells.
frigate: Built for speed, frigates were used for partol and escort duties. Although not as well armed as a ship of the line, their speed allowed them to chase down smaller targets.
steamer: Paddle steamers were the first naval vessels to utilise the steam engine. The ability to move in any direction regardless of wind gave them a distinct advantage.
third_rate: The pejorative "term third rate" derives from this ship but they considered to have the best tradeoff of speed and armament.
bomb_ketch: The bomb ketch was used to bombard fixed land positions from afar. The artillery mortars were fixed to the deck and fired vertically rather than a hortizonal broadside.
battery_ship: Battery ships had thicker armor than other ironclad ships and their rail mounted guns gave a far greater field of fire.
galleon: The Spanish Galleon was a heavily armed ship cappable of carrying a large cargo and travelling vast distances. Coverted by Pirates because of the purported aztec gold they carried.
doujian: The Louchuan was a literal fortress of the sea. Although these ships sometimes carried their own trebuchets they mainly served as command ships.
first_rate: A first rate was the largest ships of the line ever built. No lesser ship could repel their staggering firepower.
